Award.AwardTitle: Harmonic and functional analysis of wavelet and frame expansions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This mathematics research project by Marcin Bownik is focused on the investigation of the harmonic - and functional-analytic aspects of the mathematical theory of multi- dimensional wavelet and frame expansions. One of the main research directions of the project is the development of techniques for the construction of well-localized orthogonal wavelets for large classes of non-isotropic expansive dilations. A closely related complementary topic is the study of non-isotropic analogues of classical function spaces associated to expansive dilations. Another direction of the project is the construction of frames with desired properties such as with prescribed norms and frame operator. This line of research is closely related with the infinite dimensional generalizations of the Schur- Horn theorem.


This mathematics research project by Marcin Bownik explores the mathematical theory of wavelet and frame expansions. In recent years, wavelet and frame theory has found many applications to a wide range of disciplines including applied and computational harmonic analysis, signal processing and data compression. Some well -known examples where wavelets are a key tool include the JPEG 2000 digital image standard and fingerprint compression for data storage. This project aims to further the mathematical theory that provides the foundation for further applications of wavelets and frames.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project involved education and research activities concerning the mathematical theory of multi-dimensional wavelet and frame expansions. The results of research include 15 papers that were published in professional mathematical journals and as book chapters. The major mathematical outcomes of the project can be grouped into three categories.

The PI has investigated the problem of existence of wavelets for non-expanding dilations. These are linear transformations of the Euclidean space that expand and contract in different directions. This problem was shown to be connected with the estimates on the number of lattice points in dilated balls, which is one of the central areas of the geometry of numbers. The PI has shown the existence of wavelets for almost every choice of lattice and dilation matrix.

The famous Kadison-Singer problem was recently solved by Marcus, Spielman, and Srivastava in their breakthrough paper. This problem was known to be equivalent to several open problems in mathematical analysis which include Feichtinger's conjecture and Weaver's conjecture. In the joint work with Casazza, Markus, and Speegle the PI has obtained results improving bounds in these conjectures.

In the joint work with his former Ph.D. student, John Jasper, the PI has obtained several characterization results of frames with desired properties. This area was influenced by Kadison in 2002 who has shown an infinite dimensional extension of the famous Pythagorean Theorem. Kadison's theorem characterizes all possible diagonals of orthogonal projections and at the same time it characterizes all possible norms of Parseval frames. The PI has extended this characterization to other classes of operators such as operators with finite spectrum and unbounded operators with discrete spectrum.

Broader impacts  include advising Ph.D. students on topics related to the project. Thanks to the award students were able to travel to conferences and professional meetings which had a great impact on their professional development. In addition, my Ph.D. student, Joey Iverson, was supported as a graduate research assistant in the summer term of 2014. This had a very positive effect as it enabled Joey to concentrate solely on research and finish an impressive solo paper that was published by the Journal of Functional Analysis.

The PI disseminates his research results at professional meetings and conferences. As an example, the PI was an invited speaker at at International Conference on Wavelets and Applications at Euler International Mathematical Institute (St. Petersburg, Russia) in June 2015 and at International Workshop on Operator Theory and Applications at Washington University in July 2016. The PI was also an organizer of AMS Special Session on ``Wavelets, Frames, and Related Expansions'' at Washington University in St. Louis in October 2013.
